Award.AwardTitle: IEEE PerCom 2014 Student Travel Support Request

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom), sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society's Technical Committee on Distributed Computing (TCDP) and Technical Committee on Computer Communications (TCCC), is the flagship conference of the pervasive computing community. In addition to the main conference, the PerCom 2014 meeting will also feature 12 workshops on cutting-edge themes, a PhD Forum, work-in-progress sessions, poster and demo sessions, a panel, and 2-3 keynote talks. The conference's technical program also helps promote new directions of research in pervasive computing and communications. Areas of interest including emerging areas like smartphone sensing, participatory sensing and social networks with applications to healthcare, security, energy and sustainability are all budding career learning experiences for students. Student participation in IEEE Percom 2014, offers opportunities in international collaboration, greater understanding of the field, and an exciting view across the landscape of pervasive computing.

Institution.Name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF travel grant supported seventeen US based students (including four women and one army veteran) on a highly competitive basis to attend the IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom)  held in Budapest, Hungary (2014) and St. Louis, Missori (2015). The students came from diverse universities in the US. Without the travel support, many of these students would not have otherwise been able to attend the falgship IEEE PerCom conference and associated events including several workshops, dealing with technologically emerging and solcially relevant topics.

 

Intellectual Merit:


The supported students not only benefited from the keynote talks, technical presentations, panel discussions, PhD forum, demo and poster sessions at various events organized at the conference, but also had unique opportunities to network and exchange ideas with peers, international researchers, professionals, and application developers from academia and industry. Such experience motivated them to do high quality research and publish papers in top conferences and journals, thus further motivating them take up academic and research career.


Braoder Impacts:


Participation in the IEEE PerCom conference of the seventeen US-based graduate students (including four women) was an extremely valuable experience. This provided them the opportunity to interact with peers and senior researchers, as well as exposed them to cutting-edge research in the field of pervasive computing and communications, thus contributing to the workforce in this important field.
